title: ‘Ridiculous’ property taxes are shutting buyers out of the housing market, John McGrath says
text:
The NSW government will need to cut excessive property taxes to prevent more home seekers from being shut-out of the housing market, real estate entrepreneur John McGrath has warned.

High stamp duty and capital gains charges have long been an issue for the real estate industry, but the McGrath Estate Agents founder said there was a pressing need for changes given recent market movements.

Sydney property prices increased 3.5 per cent in the past three months alone — after falling for two years — and the recent surge was largely the result of increased demand at a time when few homeowners were listing.

Why Sydney renos are getting pricier

Mr McGrath said property taxes were exacerbating the housing shortage by spooking would-be sellers from listing, with many fearing they would pay too much money in transaction fees.

This low listing environment was in turn discouraging further homeowners from selling because there were too few homes on the market for them to move into, he said.

“The recent rebound in Sydney has been much faster than expected,” Mr McGrath said. “The market was always going to bounce back but the pace has been surprising and it’s because there are so few listings.”

McGrath further elaborated in his company’s annual McGrath Report that homebuyers in some Sydney areas were stumping up close to $100,000 in average stamp duty costs — an increase of 400 per cent after adjusting for inflation.

“This is ridiculous and penalises almost every single Australian moving around the property ladder as their life circumstances change,” Mr McGrath said.

“It’s the issue that nobody wants to talk about in government, on either side … there seems very little appetite by State Governments to find a better way. They seem addicted to the revenue it brings them.

“As a result, it’s possible that these lower levels of activity will remain for some time.”

Another factor likely to keep listing levels down was global uncertainty, according to Mr McGrath.

He expected many would-be sellers to be waiting to see how some global events played out, such as Brexit, the US-China trade war, Hong Kong-China tensions and the US election in 2020.

“We may find that until we get some resolution on these issues and clarity on the political direction of the US, listing levels will remain on the low side.”

McGrath is expecting Sydney property prices to continue growing next year with “strong but not double-digit” growth.

Suburbs where there would be standout levels of growth included Breakfast Point, Erskineville, Castle Cove, Sandringham and Kensington, he said.

Breakfast Point would experience growth because of new roadway infrastructure, while Kensington would benefit from improved access from the new light rail.

The other suburbs were becoming increasingly popular with a broad range of buyers and the lifestyle on offer was more sought after.
description: Real estate mogul John McGrath has slammed state government for crippling taxes on property transactions, which he says are driving up housing costs and making it harder to buy and sell.
